Comment:
At first I didn't liked this movie, but after seeing the whole trilogy now, I can say I really loved the movies, they all fit together really nicely, and to be fair, much of the things people hated about this movies are really just not that important.
I love the scenes were they just talk, make jokes, fight, it makes them feel real.
In the second one their travel becomes more and more dark, and the third one finishes with one big 30 minutes long war, that tights all together, this trilogy was made, from the beginning, as one large movie, divides in tree.
I can say I love this movies, not as much as TLOTR trilogy, wish is more mature, but people, go read the books again, all of them.

The Hobbit book: For Kids (But also for open mind adults)
The Hobbit movie: For Kids (But also for open mind adults)

TLOTR books: (For adults)
TLOTR movies: (For adults)

The tone of The Hobbit trilogy is just right, when you see it in retrospective.
I'll gladly make my future kids watch this movies in their young years, they are full of healthy fun, jokes, action, but also drama, sadness, danger, love, loss, etc.

It's the whole package people! ¬†

(1) He is a bit taller than the other dwarves, but note how short he appears when standing next to Elrond.

(2) He says "we eats it" ... meaning Gollum will eat Bilbo.  Gollum was not particularly choosy about what he ate ... it says in "The Hobbit" that he often would eat goblins that strayed.  And it is strongly implied in LOTR that he would steal human babies from their cradles and eat them ... and also that he had tried to eat the dead in the marshes near Mordor.

Title: The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey - Official Trailer 2 [HD]
Comment: That's Radagast the Brown, one of the three Wizards that live in Middle-earth (the other two went to the far eastern lands). He is mentioned only once in The Hobbit as being Gandalf's "cousin", and in The Lord of the Rings he is sent by Saruman to tell Gandalf that he is needed at Isengard. They're adding him into the films to expand on Gandalf's journeys with the White Council, which took place at the same time as Thorin's expedition with the Dwarves and Bilbo.

Title: The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey - Official Trailer 2 [HD]
Comment:
I unfortunately doubt a Silmarillion movie could happen for several reasons: 
It's too big a story to capture in one film, or even several.
The book is told like a historical account rather than one story, which wouldn't work on film.
And the biggest obstacle: Christopher Tolkien still holds the rights to The Silmarillion. So unless he has a change of heart or his sons sell the rights after he dies, we won't be seeing a Silmarillion movie.

Title: The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey - Official Trailer 2 [HD]
Comment: I believe that Jackson was always disappointed that some characters had to be left out of LotR due to time constraints.  Seeing how he wanted to cover as much detail as possible with The Hobbit, he decided to put some of these characters back into it to better tie-in with what he originally created.  For example, Radagast makes an appearance in the LotR books but is only mentioned in The Hobbit.  Since he was cut out of the LotR movies, he'll be given a role in The Hobbit to make up for it.

Title: The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey - Official Trailer 2 [HD]
Comment: Frodo was 33 at the very start of LOTR which, accounting for the fact that hobbits age more slowly than humans, means he would have looked to be in his early- to mid-20's.  (It is the year hobbits are considered to "come of age.")  Since he received the ring from Bilbo at that time, he basically stopped aging from then until the ring was destroyed.  So he basically would have appeared to be in his early 20's, even though he was 50 when the quest to destroy the ring happened.

Comment: Just to step in I have a large compendium book on all the lore in Middle Earth and as far as I remember the goblins are one species, while the orcs are actually twisted, tainted elves. The book is called Character From Tolkien by David Day, who has done a ton of other "guides" to Tolkien's worlds and mythos, so I guess he is some what of an authority. Obviously Tolkien may well have retconned lots of his lore so different sources could all say totally different things on one aspect of the lore.
